4: Heat oil in a wok or large skillet over high heat. Add garlic and stir-fry until fragrant.
5: Add protein and cook until browned.
6: Push the protein to one side of the wok and crack the egg into the empty space. Scramble the egg and then mix it with the protein.
7: Add the Chinese broccoli stems first, followed by the leaves. Stir-fry until slightly tender.
8: Add the noodles and the sauce. Stir-fry constantly to coat the noodles evenly and prevent sticking.
9: Cook until the noodles are heated through and the sauce has thickened slightly. Serve immediately.

name: Yum Pla Duk Foo
description: Yum Pla Duk Foo is a crispy catfish salad, a popular Thai dish known for its contrasting textures and bold flavors. Fluffy, deep-fried catfish is tossed in a vibrant dressing made with green mango, red onion, peanuts, chili, lime juice, and fish sauce. This combination creates a delightful explosion of sweet, sour, spicy, and savory notes. It is typically served with fresh vegetables for a refreshing contrast. While delicious, excessive consumption might lead to digestive discomfort due to the fried nature of the dish. Benefit : Source of protein and can be a good source of energy.
cooking_instructions: 1: Deep fry the catfish until golden brown and crispy.  2: Shred the fried catfish into fluffy pieces. 3: Prepare the dressing by combining lime juice, fish sauce, sugar (optional), and chili. 4: Toss the crispy catfish with shredded green mango, thinly sliced red onion, and peanuts.  5: Drizzle the dressing over the salad and mix well. 6: Serve immediately with fresh vegetables.

name: Pla Chon Lui Suan
description: Pla Chon Lui Suan is a vibrant Thai dish featuring steamed snakehead fish (Pla Chon) smothered in a fresh, herbaceous sauce. This dish is known for its balance of flavors and textures, showcasing the best of Thai cuisine. It's a lighter, healthier way to enjoy fish compared to fried preparations. The herbs are believed to aid digestion. People with allergies to certain herbs should take caution before eating.

cooking_instructions.1: Prepare the fish: Clean and scale the snakehead fish. You can either steam it whole or fillet it before steaming.
cooking_instructions.2: Steam the fish: Steam the fish until it's cooked through and the flesh is opaque (approximately 15-20 minutes, depending on size).
cooking_instructions.3: Prepare the sauce: In a bowl, combine lime juice, fish sauce, minced chili peppers, minced garlic, minced ginger, finely sliced lemongrass, chopped mint, chopped cilantro, thinly sliced kaffir lime leaves, and thinly sliced shallots. Add sugar to taste if desired.
cooking_instructions.4: Assemble the dish: Place the steamed fish on a serving platter. Pour the prepared sauce generously over the fish, ensuring it's well coated.
cooking_instructions.5: Garnish and serve: Garnish with roasted peanuts (optional). Serve with fresh vegetables like cabbage, lettuce, and cucumber on the side.

name: Nam Tok
description: Nam Tok, meaning 'waterfall' in Thai, is a flavorful and spicy meat salad originating from the Isan region of Thailand. It's typically made with grilled pork or beef, tossed in a vibrant dressing of fish sauce, lime juice, chili powder, toasted rice powder, and herbs like mint and cilantro.  The toasted rice powder gives it a nutty flavour and helps to thicken the sauce. Enjoy in moderation as the high sodium and spice content may not be suitable for all.

cooking_instructions.1: Grill or pan-fry the pork or beef until cooked through. Let it rest and then slice thinly.
cooking_instructions.2: In a bowl, combine fish sauce, lime juice, chili powder, toasted rice powder, and sugar (if using). Adjust to taste.
cooking_instructions.3: Add the sliced meat, red onion, mint, and cilantro to the dressing.
cooking_instructions.4: Toss well to combine all the ingredients.
cooking_instructions.5: Garnish with green onion (if using) and serve immediately with sticky rice or fresh vegetables.

name: Sai Krok Isan
description: Sai Krok Isan is a fermented pork sausage originating from northeastern Thailand (Isan). It's known for its sour and savory flavor profile, achieved through fermentation.  The fermentation process also aids digestion.  It's typically grilled or fried and served as a snack or appetizer with fresh ginger, chilies, and cabbage. Overconsumption may lead to digestive discomfort due to the fermentation process and high fat content. It's also important to ensure it's properly cooked to avoid any foodborne illnesses.
flavour_profile: Sour, Savory, Garlicky, Umami, Slightly Spicy

cooking_instructions.1: Ensure the sausage is thawed completely if frozen.
cooking_instructions.2: Preheat a grill or frying pan to medium heat.
cooking_instructions.3: If grilling, place the sausages directly on the grill grates. If frying, add a small amount of oil to the pan.
cooking_instructions.4: Cook for approximately 15-20 minutes, turning frequently to ensure even cooking and prevent burning. The sausages should be golden brown and firm to the touch.
cooking_instructions.5: Ensure the internal temperature reaches 160°F (71°C).
cooking_instructions.6: Remove from heat and let cool slightly before serving.
cooking_instructions.7: Serve with fresh ginger slices, chili peppers, and cabbage leaves.

name: Panaeng Nuea
description: Panaeng Nuea is a rich and flavorful Thai beef curry known for its thick, creamy sauce and aromatic spices. A cornerstone of Thai cuisine, it's believed to have originated in central Thailand.  The curry boasts a harmonious blend of sweet, savory, and slightly spicy notes. Key benefits include protein from the beef and antioxidants from the spices. However, the high fat content from coconut milk should be considered by those watching their cholesterol.
flavour_profile: Coconut Creamy, Savory, Mildly Spicy, Nutty, Aromatic

cooking_instructions.1: Slice the beef into bite-sized pieces.
cooking_instructions.2: Heat a pan or wok over medium heat and add a tablespoon of oil.
cooking_instructions.3: Add the Panaeng curry paste and stir-fry for 2-3 minutes until fragrant.
cooking_instructions.4: Add the beef and stir-fry until browned.
cooking_instructions.5: Pour in the coconut milk and bring to a simmer.
cooking_instructions.6: Add fish sauce and palm sugar. Stir well to dissolve.
cooking_instructions.7: Reduce heat to low and simmer for 20-30 minutes, or until the beef is tender and the sauce has thickened.
cooking_instructions.8: Add sliced kaffir lime leaves and red chilies (if using).
cooking_instructions.9: Stir in ground peanuts (if using).
cooking_instructions.10: Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Gaeng Pa
description: Gaeng Pa, also known as jungle curry, is a spicy and aromatic Thai curry that originated in the forested regions of Thailand. Unlike many Thai curries, it doesn't contain coconut milk, resulting in a lighter, broth-like consistency. It's typically made with a variety of fresh vegetables, herbs, and meats like pork, chicken, or fish. The heat comes from the use of fresh chilies, galangal, lemongrass, and other spices. Benefits include a potential boost to the immune system from the herbs and spices and a good source of vegetables. Potential side effects may include heartburn or digestive discomfort for those sensitive to spicy foods. Consuming in moderation will be beneficial.
cooking_instructions: 1: Prepare the curry paste by pounding or blending galangal, lemongrass, chilies, kaffir lime leaves, shrimp paste, and other spices into a fine paste. 2: Heat water or broth in a pot and add the curry paste. Bring to a simmer. 3: Add the meat of your choice and cook until nearly done. 4: Add the vegetables such as Thai eggplant, green beans, bamboo shoots, and baby corn. Cook until tender. 5: Season with fish sauce and palm sugar to taste. 6: Stir in fresh holy basil leaves just before serving. 7: Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Phat Woonsen
description: Phat Woonsen is a popular Thai stir-fried glass noodle dish. It's known for its light, savory, and slightly sweet flavor. Often features protein like shrimp, chicken, or tofu, and a mix of colorful vegetables. The glass noodles are low in calories and fat, making it a relatively healthy option. However, be mindful of sodium content from soy sauce and fish sauce. Some variations can be quite spicy, so adjust chili levels to your tolerance.
flavour_profile: Savory, Umami, Slightly Sweet, Smoky, (Optional: Spicy)

cooking_instructions.1: Soak glass noodles in warm water until softened (about 10-15 minutes). Drain well.
cooking_instructions.2: Prepare your protein and vegetables by chopping them into bite-sized pieces. Mince garlic and shallots.
cooking_instructions.3: Whisk egg in a small bowl.
cooking_instructions.4: Heat vegetable oil in a wok or large frying pan over medium-high heat.
cooking_instructions.5: Add garlic and shallots and stir-fry until fragrant (about 30 seconds).
cooking_instructions.6: Add your chosen protein and stir-fry until cooked through.
cooking_instructions.7: Push the protein to one side of the pan and pour in the whisked egg. Scramble the egg until cooked.
cooking_instructions.8: Add the softened glass noodles, cabbage, carrots, onions, tomatoes, and mushrooms.
cooking_instructions.9: Add soy sauce, fish sauce, oyster sauce (if using), and sugar. Stir-fry everything together, ensuring the noodles are well coated with the sauce.
cooking_instructions.10: Continue stir-frying until the vegetables are tender-crisp and the noodles are heated through (about 3-5 minutes).
cooking_instructions.11: Add green onions and white pepper (if using). Stir-fry for another minute.
cooking_instructions.12: Serve immediately.

name: Khao Pad Sapparot
description: Khao Pad Sapparot, or Pineapple Fried Rice, is a popular Thai dish known for its vibrant presentation and delightful mix of sweet and savory flavors. It features rice stir-fried with pineapple, vegetables, and often meat or seafood, served inside a hollowed-out pineapple. This dish is a feast for the eyes and the palate. While generally safe, be mindful of pineapple allergies and potential cross-contamination if consuming with seafood or meat.
cooking_instructions: 1: Cook rice and let it cool.  2: Prepare pineapple by hollowing it out. Reserve the pineapple flesh. 3: Stir-fry garlic and onions in oil until fragrant. 4: Add shrimp/chicken/tofu and cook until done. 5: Add vegetables and pineapple chunks and stir-fry. 6: Add cooked rice, curry powder, soy sauce, and fish sauce. Mix well. 7: Add egg and scramble. 8: Stir in cashews. 9: Serve inside the hollowed-out pineapple.

name: Miang Kham
description: Miang Kham is a flavorful and aromatic one-bite wrap originating from Thailand. It's a delightful explosion of sweet, sour, salty, spicy, and nutty flavors. Traditionally, betel leaves are used as the wrapper, filled with ingredients like toasted coconut, ginger, lime, shallots, peanuts, dried shrimp (often omitted for a vegetarian version), and a sweet-savory palm sugar sauce. It's known for its refreshing taste and digestive benefits. Consume in moderation as betel leaves can have mild stimulant effects.
flavour_profile: Sweet, Sour, Spicy, Salty, Nutty, Herbaceous

ingredients.Fish Sauce: Essential (can be substituted with soy sauce or vegetarian fish sauce)

cooking_instructions: 1: Prepare the palm sugar sauce by simmering palm sugar, fish sauce (or soy sauce alternative), water, and tamarind paste (optional) until thickened. Let cool.
2: Toast the coconut flakes until golden brown.
3: Roast peanuts and chop them coarsely.
4: Dice the shallots, ginger, and lime (with the peel).
5: Arrange all ingredients on a platter.
6: To assemble, place a small amount of each ingredient on a betel leaf.
7: Drizzle with the palm sugar sauce.
8: Fold or roll the betel leaf and enjoy immediately.

name: Khanom Krok
description: Khanom Krok are bite-sized coconut pancakes, a popular Thai street food. Made with coconut milk, rice flour, and sugar, they are cooked in a special indented pan over low heat. They are typically crispy on the outside and creamy on the inside. They offer a source of quick energy due to the sugar content. While delicious, moderation is key, especially for those with diabetes or weight concerns, due to the high sugar and saturated fat content from coconut milk.
flavour_profile: Coconut, Sweet, Creamy, Savory (sometimes, depending on toppings)

cooking_instructions.1: Prepare the batter: Mix coconut milk, rice flour, sugar, salt, and water until smooth.  Some recipes use two batters, one salty and one sweet.
cooking_instructions.2: Heat the pan: Grease a Khanom Krok pan generously with oil or coconut oil. Place over low heat until hot.
cooking_instructions.3: Pour the batter: Pour batter into each indentation of the pan, filling about 3/4 full.
cooking_instructions.4: Add toppings (optional): Add desired toppings like chopped scallions, corn, or taro.
cooking_instructions.5: Cook until golden: Cover the pan and cook until the edges are golden brown and the pancakes are cooked through (about 5-10 minutes).
cooking_instructions.6: Remove and serve: Use a small spatula to carefully remove the Khanom Krok from the pan.  Serve hot.

name: Roti Gluay
description: Roti Gluay is a popular Thai street food consisting of a thin, crispy roti (flatbread) filled with sliced bananas and drizzled with condensed milk and chocolate syrup (optional).  It's cooked on a hot griddle until golden brown. A delightful sweet treat enjoyed by locals and tourists alike.  Provides a quick energy boost from the bananas and carbohydrates.  Excessive consumption may lead to a sugar rush or digestive discomfort due to the richness of the ingredients.

cooking_instructions.1: Prepare or purchase roti dough. Divide into small balls.
cooking_instructions.2: Roll out each ball into a very thin, almost translucent circle.
cooking_instructions.3: Heat a flat griddle or pan over medium heat and grease with butter/margarine/oil.
cooking_instructions.4: Place the roti dough on the hot griddle.
cooking_instructions.5: Arrange sliced bananas on top of the roti.
cooking_instructions.6: Fold the sides of the roti over the bananas to create a square or rectangle.
cooking_instructions.7: Cook for 2-3 minutes per side, or until golden brown and crispy.
cooking_instructions.8: Remove from the griddle and drizzle generously with condensed milk. Add chocolate syrup or other toppings as desired.
cooking_instructions.9: Slice and serve immediately.

name: Tub Tim Grob
description: Tub Tim Grob, also known as Ruby Red Water Chestnuts, is a popular Thai dessert.  It features water chestnuts coated in red food coloring and tapioca flour, resembling rubies. These 'rubies' are served in sweetened coconut milk with shaved ice.  It's a refreshing treat, especially during hot weather.  The water chestnuts provide a slight crunch, and the coconut milk offers healthy fats. However, be mindful of the high sugar content which could affect blood sugar levels. Some artificial colorings can also cause sensitivity in some individuals.

cooking_instructions.1: Cut water chestnuts into small cubes.
cooking_instructions.2: Coat the water chestnut cubes in red food coloring.
cooking_instructions.3: Dredge the colored water chestnuts in tapioca flour, ensuring they are fully coated. Sift to remove excess flour.
cooking_instructions.4: Boil the tapioca-coated water chestnuts in water until they become translucent and float to the surface.
cooking_instructions.5: Remove the cooked water chestnuts and immediately plunge them into ice water to stop the cooking process and create a chewy texture.
cooking_instructions.6: Prepare the sweetened coconut milk by simmering coconut milk with sugar and pandan leaves (if using) until the sugar dissolves. Let it cool.
cooking_instructions.7: Assemble the dessert by placing shaved ice or crushed ice in a bowl.
cooking_instructions.8: Add the ruby-red water chestnuts on top of the ice.
cooking_instructions.9: Pour the sweetened coconut milk over the water chestnuts and ice.
cooking_instructions.10: Serve immediately.

name: Lod Chong
description: Lod Chong is a traditional Thai dessert featuring chewy, pandan-flavored rice flour noodles in sweet coconut milk.  Its vibrant green color comes from the pandan leaves, adding a fragrant aroma. A refreshing and light treat, perfect for hot weather.  Benefits include a boost of energy from the carbohydrates and a source of healthy fats from the coconut milk.  Excessive consumption might lead to blood sugar spikes due to the high sugar content.

cooking_instructions.1: Prepare the noodles: Mix rice flour with water and pandan juice (or extract).  Optional: Add a touch of lye water for a chewier texture.
cooking_instructions.2: Cook the batter: Cook the rice flour mixture in a pot or pan over medium heat, stirring constantly until it thickens into a translucent paste.
cooking_instructions.3: Form the noodles: Use a Lod Chong press or a colander with large holes to press the hot paste into ice water, forming the noodles.
cooking_instructions.4: Make the coconut milk syrup: In a separate pot, combine coconut milk and palm sugar. Heat gently until the sugar dissolves completely.
cooking_instructions.5: Assemble the dessert: Drain the noodles and place them in a serving bowl. Pour the coconut milk syrup over the noodles. Add ice and serve immediately.

name: Bua Loy
description: Bua Loy is a popular Thai dessert featuring small, colorful glutinous rice balls simmered in sweet coconut milk. The rice balls are often naturally colored with ingredients like pumpkin, pandan, and beetroot.  It's a comforting and visually appealing treat enjoyed for its sweet taste and chewy texture. Bua Loy is a good source of carbohydrates for energy, but should be consumed in moderation due to its high sugar content. Some may experience bloating due to the glutinous rice.
flavour_profile: Sweet, Coconutty, Creamy, Chewy, Aromatic (from pandan if used)

cooking_instructions.1: Prepare the colored dough: Divide glutinous rice flour into portions. Mix each portion with natural coloring agents (pumpkin puree, pandan extract, beetroot juice, etc.) and water to form a smooth, pliable dough. Roll into small balls.
cooking_instructions.2: Cook the rice balls: Bring a pot of water to a boil. Add the rice balls and cook until they float to the surface (about 3-5 minutes). Remove with a slotted spoon and set aside.
cooking_instructions.3: Prepare the coconut milk: In a separate pot, combine coconut milk, sugar, and a pinch of salt (if using). Heat gently until the sugar dissolves, stirring occasionally. Do not boil.
cooking_instructions.4: Combine and simmer: Add the cooked rice balls to the warm coconut milk. Simmer for a few minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
cooking_instructions.5: Serve: Serve warm in bowls. Garnish with sesame seeds if desired.

name: Khanom Chan
description: Khanom Chan is a visually appealing and delicious Thai steamed layer dessert. Its name translates to 'layered dessert.' It's known for its soft, slightly chewy texture and sweet, aromatic flavor, often infused with coconut milk and pandan. Traditionally, it is made in nine layers, symbolizing prosperity. While generally safe, excessive consumption might lead to blood sugar spikes due to its high sugar content.  It's a treat enjoyed on special occasions and as a daily indulgence.

cooking_instructions.1: Prepare the pandan extract by blending pandan leaves with water and straining the liquid.
cooking_instructions.2: In a large bowl, combine tapioca flour, rice flour, and sugar. Mix well.
cooking_instructions.3: Gradually add coconut milk and pandan extract (or water with food coloring) to the flour mixture, stirring until smooth. Ensure there are no lumps.
cooking_instructions.4: Divide the batter into two bowls.  Add desired food coloring to one bowl. Leave the other bowl natural (pandan color).
cooking_instructions.5: Grease a steaming tray.  Pour a thin layer of one color batter into the tray.
cooking_instructions.6: Steam for 3-5 minutes until the layer is set.
cooking_instructions.7: Pour a thin layer of the other color batter on top of the set layer.
cooking_instructions.8: Steam for another 3-5 minutes until set.
cooking_instructions.9: Repeat layers, alternating colors, until all the batter is used, steaming each layer until set.
cooking_instructions.10: After the last layer is steamed, steam for a final 15-20 minutes to ensure the entire cake is cooked through.
cooking_instructions.11: Let the Khanom Chan cool completely before cutting into squares or diamond shapes.

name: Fak Thong Sung Kaya
description: Fak Thong Sung Kaya, also known as Thai pumpkin custard, is a delightful Thai dessert. It features a creamy, rich coconut custard steamed inside a kabocha pumpkin. This sweet treat is visually appealing and offers a blend of textures - the soft pumpkin and smooth custard. The benefits include vitamins and fiber from the pumpkin. Potential side effects are related to the high sugar content, so moderation is key.
flavour_profile: Sweet, Coconutty, Pumpkin, Creamy, Hint of Vanilla
cooking_instructions:
1: Prepare the pumpkin by cutting off the top and scooping out the seeds. 
2: Mix coconut milk, palm sugar, eggs (or replacer), sugar (if using), salt, and vanilla extract (if using) in a bowl until well combined. 
3: Pour the custard mixture into the hollowed pumpkin. 
4: Steam the pumpkin until the custard is set (about 45-60 minutes), checking for doneness by inserting a toothpick. 
5: Let cool slightly before serving. You can eat the pumpkin flesh along with the custard.

name: Khanom Tom
description: Khanom Tom is a traditional Thai dessert featuring sticky rice flour dumplings filled with a sweet coconut and palm sugar mixture. These delightful treats are typically steamed or boiled and wrapped in banana leaves for a fragrant and visually appealing presentation.  A popular snack or dessert, Khanom Tom offers a source of carbohydrates for energy.  Consume in moderation due to the high sugar content, especially if you have diabetes or blood sugar concerns. Potential allergens include coconut and rice flour.
flavour_profile: Sweet, Coconutty, Slightly Salty (from coconut milk)

cooking_instructions.1: Combine sticky rice flour and coconut milk (if using) to form a dough. Knead until smooth and pliable.
cooking_instructions.2: Mix grated coconut and palm sugar together for the filling.  Add a pinch of salt if desired.
cooking_instructions.3: Take a small amount of dough and flatten it in your palm.
cooking_instructions.4: Place a spoonful of the coconut-palm sugar filling in the center of the dough.
cooking_instructions.5: Carefully wrap the dough around the filling, forming a small ball or dumpling.
cooking_instructions.6: Wrap each dumpling in a piece of banana leaf, securing it with a toothpick or by folding the leaf.
cooking_instructions.7: Steam the wrapped dumplings for about 15-20 minutes, or until the dough is cooked through and translucent.
cooking_instructions.8: Let cool slightly before serving. Remove banana leaves before eating.

name: Khao Lam
description: Khao Lam is a Thai dessert made by roasting glutinous rice with coconut milk, sugar, and sometimes beans or taro inside a bamboo stalk. The bamboo imparts a unique aroma and flavor to the rice as it cooks. It's a popular street food, especially in rural areas. Khao Lam is a good source of carbohydrates for energy. Due to its high sugar content, moderation is recommended, especially for those with diabetes.

ingredients.Salt: Optional (a pinch to balance the sweetness)

cooking_instructions: 1: Soak the glutinous rice in water for at least 4 hours, or preferably overnight.
2: Prepare the bamboo stalks by cleaning them thoroughly and ensuring one end is sealed.
3: In a bowl, mix the soaked glutinous rice with coconut milk, sugar, and a pinch of salt (if using). Add beans or taro if desired.
4: Carefully pour the rice mixture into the bamboo stalks, leaving some space at the top.
5: Seal the open end of the bamboo stalk with banana leaves or another suitable material.
6: Arrange the bamboo stalks upright in a charcoal grill or oven.
7: Roast over medium heat for approximately 1-2 hours, rotating the stalks occasionally to ensure even cooking. Monitor carefully to prevent burning.
8: Once the rice is cooked and the bamboo is slightly charred, remove from the heat and let cool slightly.
9: To serve, crack open the bamboo stalk and enjoy the fragrant rice.

name: Khanom Buang
description: Khanom Buang is a popular Thai street food snack. These crispy, crepe-like tacos are filled with both sweet and savory toppings. The sweet version often features shredded coconut, Foi Thong (egg yolk threads), and sweet cream, while the savory version includes ground shrimp, shallots, and pickled radish. Khanom Buang offers a delightful mix of textures and flavors. The crispiness is the highlight. Potential side effects may arise from allergies to shrimp or high sugar intake.

cooking_instructions.1: Prepare the batter: Combine rice flour, mung bean flour, water, and a pinch of salt. Mix well until smooth.
cooking_instructions.2: Heat a flat griddle or crepe pan over medium heat. Lightly grease with vegetable oil.
cooking_instructions.3: Pour a small ladleful of batter onto the hot griddle and spread thinly into a circular shape.
cooking_instructions.4: Cook until the edges start to lift and the crepe is slightly golden brown and crispy.
cooking_instructions.5: Add your desired toppings: For the sweet version, add grated coconut, Foi Thong, and a drizzle of palm sugar syrup. For the savory version, add ground shrimp, chopped shallots, and pickled radish.
cooking_instructions.6: Fold the crepe in half, taco-style, or leave it open-faced.
cooking_instructions.7: Remove from the griddle and serve immediately.

name: Look Choup
description: Look Choup are traditional Thai bite-sized sweets crafted to resemble miniature fruits and vegetables. Made from mung bean paste, these delightful treats are intricately shaped, colored with natural food dyes, and then coated in a shimmering agar-agar glaze. They are often enjoyed as a visually appealing and subtly sweet dessert during special occasions or as a gift.  The primary benefit is their low calorie content and natural ingredients. Since they are made using food color, some people may be allergic to certain food colors.
cooking_instructions:
1: Prepare Mung Bean Paste: Steam mung beans until soft. Mash and mix with sugar and coconut milk (if using) to form a smooth paste.
2: Shape the Paste: Mold the paste into desired fruit/vegetable shapes.
3: Color the Shapes: Divide the shapes and color them with food coloring to match the real thing.
4: Prepare Agar-Agar Glaze: Dissolve agar-agar powder in water and sugar, heat until clear.
5: Glaze the Shapes: Dip the colored shapes into the agar-agar glaze. Let it set.
6: Repeat Glazing: Repeat the glazing process 2-3 times for a shiny finish.
7: Arrange and Serve: Arrange the finished Look Choup on a platter and serve.

name: Thong Yip
description: Thong Yip, also known as Golden Cups, is a traditional Thai dessert. It's made from egg yolks, sugar, and jasmine-infused water, meticulously shaped into flower-like cups.  A symbol of prosperity, these golden treats are often served at auspicious occasions. Rich in protein from the eggs, moderation is key due to its high sugar content. Excessive consumption may lead to blood sugar spikes.

cooking_instructions.1: Prepare jasmine-infused water by steeping jasmine flowers in hot water.
cooking_instructions.2: Separate egg yolks carefully, ensuring no egg white contamination.
cooking_instructions.3: Mix egg yolks with sugar until well combined and slightly thickened.
cooking_instructions.4: Gradually add jasmine-infused water to the egg yolk mixture, stirring constantly.
cooking_instructions.5: If using, add a small amount of wheat flour or tapioca flour to bind the mixture.
cooking_instructions.6: Heat a Thong Yip mold over low heat.
cooking_instructions.7: Pour a small amount of the egg yolk mixture into the heated mold.
cooking_instructions.8: Cook until the edges are set and the Thong Yip easily releases from the mold.
cooking_instructions.9: Shape the cooked Thong Yip into flower-like cups.
cooking_instructions.10: Arrange the shaped Thong Yip on a plate and serve.

name: Thong Yot
description: Thong Yot, also known as Golden Egg Yolks Drops, are traditional Thai desserts believed to have been introduced by Portuguese explorers in the Ayutthaya period. These golden spheres are made primarily from egg yolks and sugar, offering a delightful sweetness. Enjoyed as a festive treat or sweet snack. As they are high in sugar, moderate consumption is advised, especially for those with diabetes.

cooking_instructions.1: Separate egg yolks from whites. Ensure no whites contaminate the yolks.
cooking_instructions.2: Mix egg yolks and sugar in a bowl until well combined and smooth.
cooking_instructions.3: If using, add jasmine water and food coloring to the mixture.
cooking_instructions.4: Heat sugar and water in a pan to make a syrup. Simmer until slightly thickened.
cooking_instructions.5: Using a small spoon or dropper, gently drop small portions of the egg yolk mixture into the simmering syrup.
cooking_instructions.6: Cook the Thong Yot until they float to the surface and are cooked through (about 2-3 minutes).
cooking_instructions.7: Remove the cooked Thong Yot from the syrup and let them cool completely.

name: Foi Thong
description: Foi Thong, also known as golden egg threads, is a traditional Thai dessert made from egg yolks simmered in sugar syrup. It has a delicate, sweet flavor and a unique thread-like texture. Foi Thong is often used in other Thai desserts and is considered auspicious, representing long life and prosperity. While generally safe, excessive consumption may lead to high sugar intake. Enjoy in moderation as part of a balanced diet.
cooking_instructions: 1: Separate egg yolks carefully, removing any chalazae (white cords).
2: Mix egg yolks gently to avoid incorporating too much air.
3: Prepare a sugar syrup by boiling sugar and water in a wide pan.
4: Add jasmine extract or pandan leaves to the syrup for fragrance (optional).
5: Using a special funnel or a small cup with a hole, slowly drizzle the egg yolk mixture into the simmering syrup in thin threads.
6: Cook the threads until they are set and golden in color, about 1-2 minutes.
7: Carefully remove the cooked egg threads from the syrup and arrange them into nests or coils.
8: Allow to cool before serving.

name: Cassoulet
description: Cassoulet is a hearty, slow-cooked French casserole originating from the Languedoc region. It's traditionally made with white beans, various meats (typically pork, sausage, duck confit, and sometimes mutton or goose), and aromatics. Key highlights include its rustic charm and the rich, layered flavors developed during the long cooking process. Cassoulet is a protein-rich dish, providing sustained energy. However, due to its high fat and potential sodium content, moderation is advised, especially for individuals with cardiovascular concerns.

cooking_instructions.1: Soak white beans overnight.
cooking_instructions.2: Cook the beans: Drain the soaked beans, cover with fresh water, and simmer with aromatics (onion, carrot, celery, bay leaf) until tender but not mushy. Reserve the cooking liquid.
cooking_instructions.3: Prepare the meats: Brown the sausage and pork pieces. If using duck confit, gently render some of the fat.
cooking_instructions.4: Sauté aromatics: In the rendered duck fat or olive oil, sauté the remaining chopped onion, garlic, and any other desired vegetables.
cooking_instructions.5: Combine ingredients: In a large, oven-safe pot or Dutch oven, layer the cooked beans, browned meats, sautéed aromatics, tomato paste, herbs, and enough of the bean cooking liquid to cover the ingredients. Add any additional stock if needed.
cooking_instructions.6: Simmer: Bring the mixture to a simmer on the stovetop, then cover and transfer to a preheated oven at 300°F (150°C).
cooking_instructions.7: Bake: Bake for 3-4 hours, or until the beans are very tender and the flavors have melded. Occasionally check the liquid level and add more if needed.
cooking_instructions.8: Crisp the topping (optional): In the last 30 minutes, remove the lid and sprinkle breadcrumbs over the top. Increase the oven temperature slightly to crisp the topping.
cooking_instructions.9: Rest: Let the cassoulet rest for at least 30 minutes before serving. The flavors will continue to develop as it sits.

name: Sangkhaya Fak Thong
description: Sangkhaya Fak Thong is a classic Thai dessert featuring a creamy, custard-like filling (Sangkhaya) steamed inside a whole kabocha squash (Fak Thong). This vibrant dish offers a delightful contrast in textures, with the soft, sweet squash complementing the rich, aromatic custard.  It's a popular choice for special occasions. The squash provides vitamins and fiber, while the custard offers protein and energy.  However, due to its high sugar content, individuals with diabetes should consume it in moderation.

cooking_instructions.1: Prepare the Squash: Carefully cut a lid on the top of the Kabocha squash and remove the seeds and pulp.
cooking_instructions.2: Prepare the Custard: In a bowl, whisk together coconut milk, palm sugar, eggs (or substitute), salt, and optionally, finely chopped pandan leaves.
cooking_instructions.3: Fill the Squash: Pour the custard mixture into the hollowed-out squash, ensuring it doesn't overflow.
cooking_instructions.4: Steam the Squash: Place the filled squash in a steamer basket set over boiling water. Cover and steam for 45-60 minutes, or until the custard is set.
cooking_instructions.5: Check for Doneness: Insert a knife or toothpick into the custard; it should come out clean.
cooking_instructions.6: Cool and Serve: Let the squash cool slightly before slicing into wedges and serving.  Serve warm or at room temperature.

name: Khanom Tan
description: Khanom Tan is a traditional Thai dessert made from rice flour, coconut milk, and palm sugar, steamed in small banana leaf cups. It has a light, spongy texture and a subtly sweet flavor with a hint of coconut.  Naturally vegetarian, it's a delightful treat.  Consume in moderation, as excessive sugar intake may not be suitable for all.

cooking_instructions.1: Prepare the batter: Combine rice flour, coconut milk, palm sugar, yeast, cooked rice (if using), and salt. Mix well until smooth.
cooking_instructions.2: Allow fermentation: Cover the batter and let it ferment for several hours, or overnight, in a warm place. This gives the Khanom Tan its characteristic tangy flavor.
cooking_instructions.3: Prepare banana leaf cups: Cut banana leaves into circles and fold them into small cups. Secure with toothpicks.
cooking_instructions.4: Fill the cups: Pour the fermented batter into the banana leaf cups, filling them about two-thirds full.
cooking_instructions.5: Steam the Khanom Tan: Arrange the cups in a steamer and steam over medium heat for about 15-20 minutes, or until the cakes are set and a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean.
cooking_instructions.6: Cool and serve: Let the Khanom Tan cool slightly before serving. Enjoy warm or at room temperature.

name: Khanom Mo Kaeng
description: Khanom Mo Kaeng is a traditional Thai baked custard dessert made with coconut milk, eggs (or mung beans for a vegan version), palm sugar, and taro. It boasts a smooth, creamy texture and a subtly sweet flavor. Often enjoyed warm or at room temperature, it's a popular treat for special occasions and everyday enjoyment. The use of taro adds a unique earthy note. While generally safe, excessive consumption may lead to weight gain due to its high sugar content.
flavour_profile: Sweet, Coconut, Taro, Creamy, Slightly Earthy

cooking_instructions.1: Prepare the taro: Peel and dice the taro. Steam or boil until tender.
cooking_instructions.2: Make the custard base: In a bowl, whisk together coconut milk, palm sugar, sugar (if using), salt, and eggs (or cooked and mashed mung beans). Strain the mixture to remove any lumps.
cooking_instructions.3: Combine ingredients: Add the cooked taro to the custard base. Mix well.
cooking_instructions.4: Prepare for baking: Grease a baking dish (traditionally a 'mo kaeng' pot but any oven-safe dish will work).
cooking_instructions.5: Bake: Pour the custard mixture into the prepared baking dish. Bake in a preheated oven at 175°C (350°F) for 45-60 minutes, or until the custard is set but still slightly jiggly in the center.
cooking_instructions.6: Cool and serve: Let the Khanom Mo Kaeng cool completely before serving.  Garnish with fried shallots if desired.

name: Khao Niao Sangkhaya
description: Khao Niao Sangkhaya is a classic Thai dessert featuring sweet sticky rice (khao niao) topped with a rich, creamy custard (sangkhaya). The custard is made with coconut milk, eggs (or sometimes substituted for a vegan version), sugar, and fragrant pandan leaves. This dessert is often enjoyed warm and is a popular street food and dessert option throughout Thailand. It offers a delightful combination of textures and flavors. Benefits include being a good source of carbohydrates from the rice and healthy fats from the coconut milk. Potential side effects can arise from high sugar content, so moderation is advised.
flavour_profile: Sweet, Coconutty, Creamy, Pandan, Slightly Salty (from the rice)

cooking_instructions.1: Prepare the sticky rice: Soak sticky rice in water for at least 4 hours, or preferably overnight. Drain well.
cooking_instructions.2: Steam the sticky rice: Steam the soaked sticky rice in a steamer lined with cheesecloth or banana leaves for 30-40 minutes, or until cooked through and sticky.  While steaming, occasionally fluff the rice.
cooking_instructions.3: Prepare the sweet coconut milk for the rice: In a saucepan, combine coconut milk, sugar, and a pinch of salt. Heat over low heat, stirring until the sugar is dissolved. Do not boil.
cooking_instructions.4: Mix the rice with sweetened coconut milk: Once the rice is cooked, gently mix it with the sweet coconut milk.  Let it sit for about 15-20 minutes to absorb the liquid.
cooking_instructions.5: Prepare the sangkhaya (custard): In a bowl, whisk together coconut milk, sugar, eggs (or tofu/cornstarch mixture for vegan), pandan leaf extract (or finely chopped pandan leaves), and a pinch of salt.  If using, whisk in tapioca or rice flour for a thicker custard.
cooking_instructions.6: Cook the sangkhaya: Pour the custard mixture into a heatproof bowl or double boiler. Cook over simmering water (or directly on very low heat), stirring constantly, until the custard thickens to a coating consistency. This will take about 15-20 minutes. Be careful not to curdle the eggs if using.
cooking_instructions.7: Assemble and serve: Spoon the sweet sticky rice onto a plate. Top with a generous amount of the sangkhaya custard. Garnish with sesame seeds (optional). Serve warm or at room temperature.

name: Khanom Kluay
description: Khanom Kluay is a classic Thai steamed banana cake. This sweet treat features a wonderfully soft and slightly sticky texture, infused with the natural sweetness of ripe bananas and a hint of coconut milk. It's a popular snack or dessert, often enjoyed at room temperature or slightly chilled. Made with simple ingredients, Khanom Kluay offers a comforting and satisfying taste of Thailand. As it is high in sugar, moderate consumption is advised.

cooking_instructions.1: Mash the ripe bananas until smooth.
cooking_instructions.2: In a bowl, combine rice flour, tapioca flour, sugar, and salt. Mix well.
cooking_instructions.3: Add the mashed bananas and coconut milk to the flour mixture. Stir until well combined and smooth.
cooking_instructions.4: Pour the mixture into small heatproof cups or molds.
cooking_instructions.5: Steam the cups for 15-20 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean.
cooking_instructions.6: Let the Khanom Kluay cool slightly before serving. Garnish with grated coconut, if desired.

name: Khanom Pang Na Moo
description: Khanom Pang Na Moo is a popular Thai street food consisting of crispy fried bread topped with a flavorful minced pork mixture. The pork is typically seasoned with garlic, coriander root, pepper, and fish sauce, then spread generously on the bread slices before deep-frying to golden perfection. It's often served with a sweet chili sauce or a refreshing cucumber relish. Benefits include a satisfying combination of textures and flavors, though it can be high in fat due to the deep-frying process. Moderation is key for those watching their calorie intake.
flavour_profile: Savory, Garlicky, Crispy, Slightly Sweet, Peppery
cooking_instructions:
1: Prepare the pork mixture: In a bowl, combine ground pork, minced garlic, chopped coriander root, ground white pepper, fish sauce, and egg. Mix well.
2: Spread the pork mixture: Spread the pork mixture evenly on slices of white bread.
3: Heat the oil: Heat vegetable oil in a deep pan or wok over medium heat.
4: Fry the bread: Carefully place the bread slices (pork-side down) into the hot oil. Fry until golden brown and crispy, about 2-3 minutes per side.
5: Drain the excess oil: Remove the fried bread from the oil and place on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
6: Slice and serve: Cut the fried bread into smaller, bite-sized pieces.
7: Serve with sweet chili sauce or cucumber relish.

name: Poo Pad Phong Karee
description: Poo Pad Phong Karee is a popular Thai stir-fried crab dish in a rich and aromatic yellow curry sauce. The sauce is a creamy, savory, and slightly sweet blend of curry powder, eggs, milk or coconut milk, and aromatics. This dish is a favourite due to its complex flavors and tender crab meat. It's relatively high in cholesterol and fat, so moderation is advised. It may not be suitable for people with shellfish allergies.

cooking_instructions.1: Prepare the crab: Clean and cut the crab into manageable pieces or use pre-cooked crab meat.
cooking_instructions.2: Prepare the sauce: In a bowl, whisk together curry powder, eggs, milk or coconut milk, fish sauce, oyster sauce, and sugar. Adjust seasonings to taste.
cooking_instructions.3: Sauté aromatics: Heat vegetable oil in a wok or large pan over medium-high heat. Add chopped onion and garlic and sauté until fragrant.
cooking_instructions.4: Add crab: Add the crab pieces to the wok and stir-fry until cooked through or heated through if using pre-cooked crab.
cooking_instructions.5: Pour in the sauce: Pour the curry sauce mixture over the crab and cook, stirring constantly, until the sauce thickens and coats the crab.
cooking_instructions.6: Add celery (optional): Stir in chopped celery for added texture and flavor.
cooking_instructions.7: Serve: Serve immediately over rice. Garnish with cilantro or green onions if desired.

name: Goong Chae Nam Pla
description: Goong Chae Nam Pla is a popular Thai seafood dish featuring raw shrimp marinated in a flavorful fish sauce dressing. The dish is known for its vibrant and spicy flavors, often accompanied by fresh herbs and vegetables.  It's a quick and easy dish to prepare. However, consuming raw seafood carries a risk of foodborne illness. Ensure shrimp is very fresh and from a reputable source. People with compromised immune systems, pregnant women, and young children should avoid consuming raw seafood. Benefits may include protein from the shrimp and vitamins and minerals from the accompanying vegetables.
cooking_instructions: 1: Prepare the shrimp: Peel, devein, and butterfly the raw shrimp.  Ensure they are very fresh.
2: Marinate the shrimp: Arrange the shrimp on a plate. In a bowl, combine fish sauce, lime juice, minced garlic, and chopped Thai chilies. Adjust the amount of chilies to your spice preference.
3: Add sugar if desired to balance the flavours.
4: Pour the marinade over the shrimp, ensuring they are evenly coated.
5: Garnish: Sprinkle with fresh mint leaves, cilantro, chopped lemongrass (if using), and sliced shallots (if using).
6: Serve: Serve immediately with sliced cucumber and bitter gourd (if using). The lime juice will slightly 'cook' the shrimp but not entirely.

name: Pla Muk Pad Prik Pao
description: Pla Muk Pad Prik Pao is a popular Thai stir-fry featuring squid (Pla Muk) cooked in a flavorful chili jam sauce (Prik Pao). This dish is known for its vibrant flavors and tender squid. It provides a good source of protein from the squid. However, be mindful of the sodium content from the chili jam and fish sauce. Also, individuals with shellfish allergies should avoid this dish.
cooking_instructions: 1: Prepare the squid by cleaning and slicing it into rings or pieces. 2: Mince garlic and chop onion and bell peppers. 3: Heat vegetable oil in a wok or large pan over medium-high heat. 4: Add garlic and onion and stir-fry until fragrant. 5: Add the squid and stir-fry until it turns opaque and slightly firm. 6: Add chili jam, fish sauce, and sugar. Stir-fry until the squid is coated in the sauce. 7: Add bell peppers and stir-fry until they are tender-crisp. 8: If using, add Thai basil and stir-fry until wilted. 9: Adjust seasoning with lime juice or soy sauce, if needed. 10: Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Hoy Shell Pad Cha
description: Hoy Shell Pad Cha is a spicy and flavorful Thai stir-fry featuring succulent scallops as the star. 'Pad Cha' refers to a specific stir-fry preparation with a combination of herbs and spices that create a distinct aromatic and fiery profile. Key ingredients include fresh chilies, garlic, galangal, lemongrass, peppercorns, and holy basil. This dish is rich in protein and various vitamins and minerals from the seafood and vegetables. However, the high spice level might be irritating for people with sensitive stomachs. May contain shellfish allergens.
flavour_profile: Spicy > Savory > Herbal > Umami > Slightly Sweet
cooking_instructions:
1: Prepare the Pad Cha paste: Finely chop or grind garlic, chilies, galangal, lemongrass, and peppercorns into a paste.
2: Prepare the scallops: Rinse the scallops and pat them dry.  Season lightly with salt and pepper.
3: Stir-fry the paste: Heat vegetable oil in a wok or large skillet over high heat. Add the Pad Cha paste and stir-fry until fragrant (about 1 minute).
4: Add vegetables (optional): If using, add onions, bell peppers, baby corn, and mushrooms to the wok and stir-fry for 2-3 minutes until slightly softened.
5: Add the scallops: Add the scallops to the wok and stir-fry until cooked through and slightly browned (about 2-3 minutes, depending on size). Be careful not to overcook them.
6: Add sauces: Add fish sauce, oyster sauce, and soy sauce (if using) to the wok. Stir well to combine.
7: Add Holy Basil: Stir in the holy basil leaves just before the end of cooking.
8: Serve: Serve immediately over rice.

name: Pla Kapong Neung See Ew
description: Pla Kapong Neung See Ew is a classic Thai steamed fish dish, typically made with Asian Seabass (Pla Kapong).  The fish is steamed to perfection, resulting in a tender and flaky texture, then doused in a savory and aromatic soy sauce-based sauce. Ginger, scallions, and chilies are often added for extra flavor and fragrance.  This dish is a healthy and delicious option, rich in protein and omega-3 fatty acids. Potential side effects are minimal, but those with soy allergies should exercise caution.
flavour_profile: Savory, Umami, Ginger, Slightly Sweet, Aromatic
cooking_instructions:
1: Prepare the fish: Clean and scale the Pla Kapong. Make shallow slits on both sides.
2: Prepare the steaming setup: Use a steamer rack in a pot or a bamboo steamer.
3: Arrange the fish: Place the fish on a heatproof plate or dish that fits in your steamer.  Stuff ginger slices and scallions inside the fish cavity and on top.
4: Steam the fish: Bring water in the steamer to a boil. Carefully place the plate with the fish inside the steamer. Cover and steam for 12-15 minutes, or until the fish is cooked through (flesh flakes easily with a fork).
5: Prepare the sauce: While the fish is steaming, prepare the sauce. In a small saucepan, combine soy sauce, sugar (if using), minced garlic, ginger, chopped chilies (if using), sesame oil (if using), and a splash of water. Bring to a simmer and cook for a few minutes until the sugar is dissolved and the sauce slightly thickens.
6: Serve: Once the fish is cooked, carefully remove it from the steamer. Discard the ginger and scallions that were stuffed inside.
7: Garnish and Sauce: Pour the prepared sauce over the steamed fish. Garnish with fresh scallions and cilantro (optional).
8: Serve immediately.  Best served with steamed rice.

name: Yam Talay
description: Yam Talay is a spicy and sour Thai seafood salad. This vibrant dish features a mix of shrimp, squid, mussels, and other seafood tossed with a tangy dressing of lime juice, fish sauce, chili peppers, and herbs. A refreshing and flavorful appetizer or light meal, Yam Talay is a good source of protein and essential nutrients. However, those with seafood allergies should avoid it, and excessive consumption of chili peppers may cause digestive discomfort. The spiciness can be adjusted to individual preferences.
cooking_instructions: 1: Prepare the seafood: Clean and cook the shrimp, squid, and mussels separately. Avoid overcooking to maintain tenderness.
2: Prepare the dressing: In a bowl, whisk together lime juice, fish sauce, chopped chili peppers, and sugar (if using).
3: Chop the vegetables: Thinly slice red onion, and roughly chop cilantro and mint.
4: Combine ingredients: In a large bowl, combine the cooked seafood, sliced red onion, cilantro, mint, and tomatoes (if using).
5: Dress the salad: Pour the prepared dressing over the seafood and vegetables. Toss gently to combine.
6: Garnish and serve: Garnish with crushed peanuts (if using) and serve immediately.

name: Tom Saap
description: Tom Saap is a spicy and sour Thai soup, known for its intense flavors. It's typically made with pork ribs, galangal, lemongrass, kaffir lime leaves, chilies, and fish sauce.  The soup offers a delightful blend of savory, spicy, and acidic notes. Potential side effects include heartburn or digestive discomfort for those sensitive to spicy foods.It provides a boost to the immune system because of the herbs and spices used.
cooking_instructions: 1: Boil pork ribs until tender. 2: Add galangal, lemongrass, and kaffir lime leaves to the broth. 3: Stir in fish sauce, chilies, and lime juice. 4: Simmer for a few minutes to allow the flavors to meld. 5: Garnish with cilantro and roasted rice powder (if using). 6: Serve hot.

name: Gaeng Jued
description: Gaeng Jued, also known as clear soup, is a mild and nourishing Thai soup. It typically features a light broth made with vegetables, ground pork or chicken, tofu, and glass noodles.  It's a comforting and easily digestible dish, often enjoyed for its hydrating properties and mild flavors.  Key highlight: It's a very versatile dish with ingredients easily swapped. Side effects are rare, though those with soy allergies should be mindful of tofu content. High sodium if broth is not homemade.
flavour_profile: Savory, Light, Umami, Mildly Sweet (from vegetables)
cooking_instructions: 1: Prepare the broth: In a pot, bring chicken or vegetable broth to a boil.  2: Sauté garlic:  Lightly sauté minced garlic in a separate pan until fragrant.  3: Add aromatics to broth:  Add the sautéed garlic to the boiling broth. 4: Add protein (if using): Add ground pork or chicken and cook until browned. 5: Add vegetables: Add vegetables and cook until softened. 6: Add tofu and noodles: Add tofu and glass noodles. Cook until noodles are translucent and tofu is heated through. 7: Season: Season with soy sauce or fish sauce and white pepper to taste. 8: Garnish: Garnish with fresh cilantro before serving.

name: Phat Pet Moo
description: Pad Pet Moo is a fiery and flavorful Thai stir-fry featuring tender pork, vibrant chilies, aromatic herbs like galangal and kaffir lime leaves, and crisp vegetables.  It's a quick and satisfying dish known for its bold, spicy kick.  Enjoy in moderation due to the high sodium and fat content.
cooking_instructions: 1: Prepare the ingredients: Slice pork into bite-sized pieces. Chop vegetables (if using).
2: Heat oil in a wok or large pan over medium-high heat.
3: Add red curry paste and stir-fry until fragrant (about 1-2 minutes).
4: Add pork and stir-fry until cooked through.
5: Add vegetables (if using) and stir-fry for a few minutes until slightly tender.
6: Add fish sauce, sugar, and kaffir lime leaves. Stir well to combine.
7: Adjust seasoning to taste. Add more chilies for extra spice.
8: Stir in Thai basil (if using) just before serving.
9: Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Phat Prik King
description: Phat Prik King is a dry Thai curry stir-fry known for its intense flavors. It features a fragrant red curry paste base, typically cooked with meat (often pork or chicken) or tofu, green beans, and kaffir lime leaves. The dish is characterized by its lack of coconut milk, resulting in a drier consistency and a concentrated, spicy flavor. Rich in protein and potentially vegetables like green beans, it can be a nutritious meal. However, the high sodium and spice content may be unsuitable for individuals with certain dietary restrictions or sensitivities.
flavour_profile: Spicy, Savory, Aromatic, Umami, Slightly Sweet

cooking_instructions.1: Prepare ingredients: Cut meat or tofu into bite-sized pieces, trim green beans, and finely slice kaffir lime leaves.
cooking_instructions.2: Heat oil in a wok or large skillet over medium-high heat.
cooking_instructions.3: Add red curry paste and stir-fry for 1-2 minutes until fragrant.
cooking_instructions.4: Add meat or tofu and stir-fry until cooked through.
cooking_instructions.5: Add green beans and stir-fry for 2-3 minutes until slightly tender.
cooking_instructions.6: Add fish sauce, sugar, and soy sauce (if using). Stir-fry to combine.
cooking_instructions.7: Stir in sliced kaffir lime leaves and red bell pepper (if using).
cooking_instructions.8: Garnish with Thai basil (if using) and serve hot with rice.

name: Phat Ruam Mit
description: Phat Ruam Mit, meaning 'mixed stir-fry,' is a vibrant Thai dish featuring a medley of vegetables and often a protein like tofu, chicken, or pork.  It's a quick and healthy meal, rich in vitamins and fiber from the diverse vegetables. The sauce is typically a blend of soy sauce, oyster sauce (optional), garlic, and sugar.  Some variations may include chilies for added spice. Consume in moderation as high sodium sauces can affect blood pressure. Be mindful of allergic reactions with shellfish allergy due to oyster sauce. The dish is customizable based on your own preference for vegetables.
flavour_profile: Savory, Umami, Slightly Sweet, Garlicky, (Optional) Spicy
cooking_instructions: 1: Prepare the ingredients: Chop vegetables and protein into bite-sized pieces. Mince garlic and chilies (if using).
2: Prepare the sauce: In a small bowl, combine soy sauce, oyster sauce (if using), sugar, and a little water. Mix well.
3: Heat oil in a wok or large skillet over high heat.
4: Add garlic and chilies (if using) and stir-fry for a few seconds until fragrant.
5: Add the protein and stir-fry until cooked through.
6: Add the vegetables and stir-fry until tender-crisp.
7: Pour in the sauce and stir-fry until the sauce thickens and coats the vegetables and protein.
8: Stir in Thai basil (if using).
9: Serve hot with rice.

name: Phat Makheua Yao
description: Phat Makheua Yao is a flavorful Thai stir-fry featuring long eggplant as the star. The eggplant is typically stir-fried with garlic, chilies, soy sauce, and often basil, creating a savory and slightly spicy dish. It is a popular vegetarian option in Thailand, known for its simple yet satisfying flavors. Key highlights include its rich flavors and ease of preparation. Benefits include being a good source of fiber and vitamins. Potential side effects are minimal, mainly concerning allergies to ingredients or sensitivity to spice.
flavour_profile: Savory, Spicy, Umami, Slightly Sweet, Herbal
cooking_instructions: 1: Prepare the eggplant: Wash and cut the eggplant into 2-inch long pieces. You can soak it in salted water to prevent discoloration.
2: Prepare the aromatics: Mince the garlic and chilies.
3: Stir-fry the eggplant: Heat vegetable oil in a wok or large pan over medium-high heat. Add the eggplant and stir-fry until softened and slightly browned.
4: Add aromatics: Add the minced garlic and chilies to the pan and stir-fry for another minute until fragrant.
5: Add the sauce: Add soy sauce, vegetarian oyster sauce (if using), and sugar to the pan. Stir well to combine and coat the eggplant.
6: Simmer: Add a little water if necessary to create a sauce. Let the mixture simmer for a few minutes, allowing the flavors to meld.
7: Add basil: Stir in the Thai basil leaves just before removing from heat.
8: Serve: Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Tao Hoo Song Kreuang
description: Tao Hoo Song Kreuang is a classic Thai vegetarian dish featuring silken tofu simmered in a rich and fragrant coconut milk-based sauce. It's traditionally flavored with a blend of aromatic herbs and spices, creating a complex and savory flavor profile. Key ingredients like galangal, lemongrass, and kaffir lime leaves provide its signature Thai aroma. A good source of plant-based protein from the tofu, it's also relatively low in calories and can be adapted to be gluten-free. Potential side effects are minimal but those sensitive to coconut milk should consume in moderation.
flavour_profile: Savory, Creamy, Aromatic (lemongrass, galangal), Mildly Spicy, Slightly Sweet

cooking_instructions.1: Prepare the aromatics: Finely chop galangal, lemongrass, and chilies (if using). Tear kaffir lime leaves to release their aroma.
cooking_instructions.2: Sauté the aromatics: Heat vegetable oil in a pan or wok over medium heat. Add chopped galangal, lemongrass, and chilies (if using). Sauté until fragrant (about 2-3 minutes).
cooking_instructions.3: Add tofu and coconut milk: Gently add silken tofu (cut into cubes) to the pan. Pour in coconut milk and bring to a simmer.
cooking_instructions.4: Season and simmer: Season with soy sauce and sugar (if using). Gently stir to combine. Simmer for about 10-10 minutes, allowing the flavors to meld and the sauce to thicken slightly. Be careful not to break the tofu.
cooking_instructions.5: Garnish and serve: Garnish with fresh Thai basil (if using). Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Gaeng Liang
description: Gaeng Liang is a spicy and peppery Thai vegetable soup, known for its healthful qualities. It is packed with vitamins and minerals from the diverse array of vegetables used. Key ingredients typically include gourds, luffa, mushrooms, and herbs, simmered in a flavorful broth seasoned with shrimp paste (optional, can be omitted for strict vegetarian version), peppercorns, and chilies. This soup is known for its warming properties and is often consumed during colder months or to combat colds. While generally beneficial, individuals sensitive to spice should consume in moderation due to the presence of chilies and peppercorns.
flavour_profile: Peppery, Spicy, Savory, Herbal, Slightly Sweet
cooking_instructions: 1: Prepare the spice paste by grinding together peppercorns, chilies, onion, garlic, galangal, and shrimp paste (if using). 2: Bring vegetable broth to a boil in a pot. 3: Add the spice paste to the boiling broth and stir well. 4: Add the luffa, pumpkin, and mushrooms to the pot. 5: Simmer until the vegetables are tender. 6: Stir in the holy basil just before serving. 7: Season with fish sauce (optional) and salt to taste. Serve hot.

name: Phat Fak Thong Sai Kai
description: Phat Fak Thong Sai Kai is a popular Thai stir-fry dish featuring kabocha squash (fak thong) and egg (kai). This vibrant dish offers a delightful combination of sweet and savory flavors. Kabocha squash is packed with vitamins and antioxidants, making this a healthy and delicious meal.  While generally safe, consuming large amounts of squash may lead to mild digestive discomfort in some individuals. Typically enjoyed as a quick and satisfying lunch or dinner option.
cooking_instructions: 1: Prepare the squash: Peel, deseed, and dice the kabocha squash into bite-sized pieces.
2: Prepare Aromatics: Mince the garlic. Chop the green onions and chilies (if using).
3: Scramble the eggs: Lightly beat the eggs with a pinch of salt and set aside.
4: Stir-fry garlic: Heat vegetable oil in a wok or large skillet over medium-high heat. Add the minced garlic and stir-fry until fragrant (about 30 seconds).
5: Add squash: Add the diced kabocha squash to the wok and stir-fry for 5-7 minutes, or until slightly softened.
6: Cook the eggs: Push the squash to one side of the wok. Pour in the beaten eggs and scramble until cooked through.
7: Combine and sauce: Mix the scrambled eggs with the squash. Add oyster sauce, soy sauce, sugar, and fish sauce (if using). Stir-fry to combine.
8: Finish and serve: Add the chopped green onions and chilies (if using). Stir-fry for another minute. Serve hot with rice.

name: Phat Bai Horapha
description: Phat Bai Horapha, also known as Thai Basil Stir-Fry, is a vibrant and aromatic dish featuring meat (typically chicken, pork, or beef) stir-fried with holy basil. It's a staple in Thai cuisine, known for its bold flavors. Holy basil has potential health benefits, including antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. However, excessive consumption might cause mild gastrointestinal discomfort in some individuals.

cooking_instructions.1: Prepare ingredients: Chop meat into bite-sized pieces. Mince garlic and chili. Wash and pick holy basil leaves.
cooking_instructions.2: Heat oil in a wok or large skillet over high heat.
cooking_instructions.3: Add garlic and chili, stir-fry until fragrant (about 30 seconds).
cooking_instructions.4: Add meat and stir-fry until cooked through.
cooking_instructions.5: Add soy sauce, fish sauce, sugar (if using), and oyster sauce (if using). Stir-fry to combine.
cooking_instructions.6: Add onions, bell peppers, and green beans (if using). Stir-fry until slightly softened.
cooking_instructions.7: Add holy basil leaves and stir-fry until wilted (about 15 seconds).
cooking_instructions.8: Serve immediately with steamed rice.

name: Phat See Ew Sen Yai
description: Phat See Ew Sen Yai is a popular Thai stir-fried noodle dish featuring wide rice noodles (Sen Yai). It's known for its savory and slightly sweet flavor, achieved with soy sauce, Chinese broccoli (gai lan), egg, and often a protein like chicken, pork, or tofu.  It's a quick and satisfying meal, providing carbohydrates for energy and protein for muscle building. Potential side effects are related to high sodium content if excessive soy sauce is used. Individuals with soy or egg allergies should avoid this dish.

cooking_instructions.1: Prepare the noodles: If using dried noodles, soak them according to package directions. Fresh noodles might need to be loosened.
cooking_instructions.2: Prepare the ingredients: Chop the Chinese broccoli into bite-sized pieces. Mince the garlic. Slice the protein into thin pieces.
cooking_instructions.3: Scramble the egg: Heat a wok or large pan over medium-high heat. Add a little oil and scramble the egg until cooked but still slightly soft. Remove from the wok and set aside.
cooking_instructions.4: Stir-fry the protein: Add more oil to the wok. Stir-fry the protein until cooked through. Remove from the wok and set aside.
cooking_instructions.5: Stir-fry the garlic and vegetables: Add more oil to the wok. Add the minced garlic and stir-fry until fragrant (about 30 seconds). Add the Chinese broccoli and stir-fry until slightly softened.
cooking_instructions.6: Add the noodles and sauces: Add the noodles to the wok. Pour in the soy sauce, dark soy sauce, and oyster sauce. Stir-fry well to coat the noodles evenly.
cooking_instructions.7: Combine and finish: Add the scrambled egg and the cooked protein back to the wok. Stir-fry everything together until heated through and the noodles are well-coated and softened.
cooking_instructions.8: Season and serve: Add sugar (optional), white pepper (optional), and a splash of vinegar (optional) to taste. Stir-fry for another minute. Serve immediately.

name: Phat Thai Goong Sot
description: Phat Thai Goong Sot is a popular Thai stir-fried noodle dish featuring fresh shrimp (goong sot). It combines rice noodles, shrimp, tofu, bean sprouts, garlic chives, and peanuts in a sweet, sour, and savory sauce made from tamarind pulp, fish sauce, palm sugar, and garlic. A squeeze of lime adds a final zing. It is enjoyed worldwide. Rich in protein, carbohydrates, and various vitamins. While generally safe, those with shellfish allergies should avoid it. High sodium and sugar content might be a concern for some.
cooking_instructions: 1: Soak rice noodles in warm water until softened.
2: Prepare the sauce by combining tamarind pulp, fish sauce, palm sugar, and minced garlic.
3: Stir-fry tofu until golden brown.
4: Add shrimp and cook until pink.
5: Push ingredients to one side, crack an egg (optional) and scramble lightly.
6: Add softened noodles and the prepared sauce. Toss well.
7: Add bean sprouts, garlic chives, and chopped peanuts. Stir-fry until noodles are heated through.
8: Serve immediately with a lime wedge and chili flakes (optional).

name: Khao Pad Kai
description: Khao Pad Kai, a staple of Thai cuisine, is a flavorful fried rice dish featuring rice stir-fried with egg, vegetables, and savory seasonings. Often enjoyed as a quick and satisfying meal, it's a popular street food and restaurant dish. Khao Pad Kai provides carbohydrates for energy and protein from the egg. While generally safe, excessive oil can lead to digestive discomfort for some.

cooking_instructions.1: Heat vegetable oil in a wok or large frying pan over medium-high heat.
cooking_instructions.2: Add minced garlic and chopped onion (if using) and stir-fry until fragrant (about 1 minute).
cooking_instructions.3: Push the garlic and onion to one side of the pan and crack the egg(s) into the empty space. Scramble the egg(s) until cooked but still slightly soft.
cooking_instructions.4: Add the cooked rice to the pan and break it up with a spatula. Stir-fry with the egg and aromatics until the rice is heated through and evenly coated.
cooking_instructions.5: Season with soy sauce, fish sauce, and sugar (if using). Adjust the amounts to your taste.
cooking_instructions.6: Add chopped tomato (if using) and stir-fry for another minute.
cooking_instructions.7: Garnish with chopped green onion and serve hot with cucumber slices and a lime wedge (if using).

name: Khao Pad Moo
description: Khao Pad Moo is a popular Thai fried rice dish made with pork. It's a staple street food, offering a satisfying and flavorful meal.  Typically uses day-old rice, resulting in a delightful texture. It provides carbohydrates for energy and protein from the pork. While generally safe, excessive oil used in preparation could contribute to high-fat intake. Be mindful of added sodium (fish sauce, soy sauce). It is a flexible dish that can be changed to your taste.
flavour_profile: Salty, Savory, Umami, Slightly Sweet, Smoky
cooking_instructions: 1: Prepare ingredients: Dice pork, chop garlic and onion, and have cooked rice ready. 2: Heat oil in a wok or large pan over medium-high heat. 3: Add garlic and onion, stir-fry until fragrant. 4: Add pork and cook until browned. 5: Push ingredients to one side of the pan and crack egg into the empty space. Scramble the egg. 6: Add cooked rice to the pan and mix well with the other ingredients. 7: Season with soy sauce, fish sauce, and sugar (if using). 8: Add vegetables (if using) and stir-fry until heated through. 9: Serve hot, garnished with green onions and a lime wedge.

name: Khao Pad Goong
description: Khao Pad Goong is a classic Thai fried rice dish featuring succulent shrimp (Goong) as the star ingredient. It's a flavorful and satisfying meal, perfect for a quick lunch or dinner. This dish is often enjoyed for its balance of savory, sweet, and slightly tangy notes. It is a good source of carbohydrates and protein. Potential side effects can arise from allergies to shrimp or other ingredients, and high sodium content may be a concern for some.
flavour_profile: Savory, Umami, Sweet, Slightly Tangy, Garlicky
cooking_instructions: 1: Heat vegetable oil in a wok or large frying pan over medium-high heat.
2: Add minced garlic and chopped onion (if using) and stir-fry until fragrant (about 30 seconds).
3: Push the garlic and onion to one side of the wok. Crack the egg into the empty space and scramble until cooked through.
4: Add the shrimp to the wok and stir-fry until pink and cooked (about 2-3 minutes).
5: Add the cooked rice to the wok and break it up with a spatula.
6: Add soy sauce, fish sauce, and sugar to the rice mixture. Stir-fry to combine all ingredients and ensure the rice is evenly coated with the sauce.
7: Add diced tomato (if using) and green onion. Stir-fry for another minute until heated through.
8: Serve immediately, garnished with fresh lime wedges and chili flakes (if desired).

name: Khao Pad Sapparot Talay
description: Khao Pad Sapparot Talay is a delicious Thai fried rice dish served in a pineapple half. It features fragrant rice stir-fried with a medley of seafood (talay), such as shrimp, squid, and mussels, along with pineapple chunks, vegetables, curry powder, and cashew nuts.  It's a flavorful and visually appealing dish, offering a balance of sweet, savory, and spicy notes. The pineapple adds a tropical sweetness, while the curry powder provides warmth and depth. The seafood contributes a briny flavor. Benefits include being a good source of protein and carbohydrates. Potential side effects could be allergic reactions to seafood or sensitivities to spices. Moderation is key.
flavour_profile: Sweet, Savory, Spicy, Fruity, Nutty, Briny
cooking_instructions: 1: Cook rice according to package directions and let cool.
2: Prepare seafood: Clean and chop shrimp, squid, and mussels. Set aside.
3: Prepare pineapple: Cut pineapple in half lengthwise. Scoop out the flesh, leaving the shell intact. Chop the pineapple flesh into bite-sized pieces.
4: Heat vegetable oil in a wok or large skillet over medium-high heat.
5: Add chopped onion and garlic and stir-fry until fragrant.
6: Add seafood and stir-fry until cooked through.
7: Add cooked rice, pineapple chunks, curry powder, soy sauce, fish sauce, and sugar (if using).
8: Stir-fry until well combined and heated through. If using egg, push the rice to one side of the wok, crack the egg into the empty space and scramble. Then mix the egg with the rice.
9: Add cashew nuts and vegetables (if using) and stir-fry for another minute.
10: Spoon the fried rice mixture into the pineapple shell.
11: Garnish with spring onion and cilantro. Serve immediately.

name: Khao Man Gai
description: Khao Man Gai is a beloved Thai street food dish consisting of succulent poached chicken served over fragrant rice cooked in chicken broth. Often served with a flavorful dipping sauce made from ginger, garlic, chili, and soy sauce. It's a comforting and satisfying meal. Highlights include the tender chicken and aromatic rice. Benefits include being a good source of protein. Potential side effects could arise from high sodium content or if allergic to any ingredients.
flavour_profile: Savory, Garlicky, Ginger, Rich (chicken broth), Umami
cooking_instructions: 1: Prepare the chicken broth by simmering chicken bones with aromatics like ginger and garlic.
2: Cook the rice in the chicken broth. This infuses it with flavor.
3: Poach the chicken in the remaining broth until cooked through.
4: Prepare the dipping sauce by combining ginger, garlic, chili, soy sauce, and other ingredients to taste.
5: Slice the poached chicken and serve over the fragrant rice.
6: Garnish with cucumber slices and cilantro.

name: Ba Mee Moo Daeng
description: Ba Mee Moo Daeng is a popular Thai street food dish featuring egg noodles (Ba Mee) served with slices of roasted red pork (Moo Daeng).  Often accompanied by crispy wontons, leafy greens like bok choy, and a flavorful broth. The dish is a quick and satisfying meal. The protein and carbohydrates provide energy. However, be mindful of the sodium content from the broth and sauces. Some versions may be high in sugar.

cooking_instructions.1: Prepare the Roasted Red Pork (Moo Daeng): If not pre-made, roast pork with a marinade of red food coloring, honey, soy sauce, and five-spice powder until cooked and slightly caramelized.
cooking_instructions.2: Cook the Noodles: Boil egg noodles according to package directions until al dente. Drain and set aside.
cooking_instructions.3: Prepare the Broth: Heat chicken or pork broth in a pot. Season with soy sauce and a touch of sugar to taste.
cooking_instructions.4: Assemble the Dish: In a bowl, place a portion of cooked noodles. Top with slices of Roasted Red Pork, blanched bok choy, and crispy wontons (if using).
cooking_instructions.5: Ladle the Broth: Pour a generous amount of hot broth over the noodles and toppings.
cooking_instructions.6: Garnish: Drizzle with garlic oil, and add chili flakes or paste, vinegar, and sugar to your taste.

name: Kuay Teow Reua
description: Kuay Teow Reua, also known as Boat Noodles, is a rich and flavorful Thai noodle soup traditionally sold from boats on the canals of Thailand. The broth is typically dark and complex, incorporating pork or beef blood, herbs, and spices. Key highlights include its intense savory flavor and the use of various cuts of meat.  Benefits include a hearty and protein-rich meal. However, due to the use of blood and sometimes MSG, individuals with dietary restrictions or sensitivities should exercise caution. Some variations may contain high sodium levels.
flavour_profile: Savory, Umami, Spicy, Herbal, Slightly Sweet, Tangy (from vinegar)
cooking_instructions:
1: Prepare the broth by simmering pork or beef bones with galangal, lemongrass, cinnamon, star anise, garlic, and dark soy sauce for several hours to develop a rich flavor.
2: Strain the broth and season with light soy sauce, fish sauce, and sugar.
3:  Mix pork/beef blood into a small amount of the broth to prevent clotting and then add it back into the main broth.
4: Blanch rice noodles until soft and pliable.
5: In a bowl, arrange the blanched noodles, slices of pork or beef, Chinese celery, bean sprouts, and morning glory.
6: Ladle the hot broth over the noodles and meat.
7: Garnish with fried garlic, pickled mustard greens, chili vinegar, and pork crackling (optional). Serve immediately.

name: Yen Ta Fo
description: Yen Ta Fo is a vibrant and flavorful Thai noodle soup distinguished by its bright pink broth, achieved through the use of fermented red bean curd. This hearty soup typically features a mix of rice noodles, fish balls, tofu, crispy fried wontons, and morning glory. It's a popular street food dish enjoyed for its unique taste and satisfying combination of textures. While generally safe, individuals with soy allergies should exercise caution due to the fermented bean curd. Enjoy in moderation as some variations can be high in sodium.
cooking_instructions: 1: Prepare the broth: Simmer chicken or vegetable stock with fermented red bean curd until the broth turns pink. Season with fish sauce, sugar, and lime juice to taste.
2: Cook the noodles: Cook rice noodles according to package directions.
3: Prepare the toppings: Cook fish balls, shrimp, and squid separately. Blanch morning glory and bean sprouts.
4: Assemble the soup: Place noodles in a bowl. Add fish balls, shrimp, squid, tofu, wontons, morning glory, and bean sprouts.
5: Pour the broth over the toppings.
6: Garnish with garlic oil and chili paste (if desired). Serve hot.

name: Kuay Teow Lui Suan
description: Kuay Teow Lui Suan is a refreshing and healthy Thai fresh spring roll dish featuring wide rice noodles (Kuay Teow) and various fresh herbs and vegetables.  It's typically served with a flavorful peanut dipping sauce. A great light meal option. The abundance of vegetables contributes to a high fiber content, aiding digestion. Be mindful of the peanut sauce if you have allergies.
cooking_instructions: 1: Prepare the peanut sauce: Blend or whisk together peanut butter, lime juice, soy sauce, sugar, garlic, chili (if using), and water until smooth. Adjust the consistency as needed.
2: Cook the rice noodles: Cook the wide rice noodles according to package directions. Drain and let cool slightly.
3: Prepare the vegetables and herbs: Wash and prepare all the vegetables and herbs. Cut carrots and cucumber into thin strips.
4: Assemble the rolls: Dip a rice paper wrapper in warm water for a few seconds until softened.

5: Lay the softened rice paper on a flat surface. Arrange a small amount of rice noodles, lettuce, carrots, cucumber (if using), bean sprouts (if using), tofu (if using), coriander, mint, and Thai basil on the lower third of the wrapper.
6: Fold the sides of the wrapper inward, then tightly roll from the bottom up, like a burrito.
7: Repeat steps 4-6 until all ingredients are used.
8: Serve immediately with the peanut dipping sauce.

name: Sakoo Sai Moo
description: Sakoo Sai Moo is a savory Thai snack featuring tapioca pearls filled with a flavorful mixture of ground pork, peanuts, and seasoned with garlic, coriander root, and palm sugar. Steamed until translucent, these bite-sized dumplings offer a delightful combination of textures and tastes.  Highlights include the chewy tapioca and savory filling. Benefits include providing carbohydrates for energy and protein. Potential side effects could arise from peanut allergies or excessive consumption of the relatively high-fat content.

cooking_instructions.1: Prepare the filling: Grind roasted peanuts coarsely. Mix ground pork with chopped garlic, coriander root paste, ground peanuts, palm sugar, fish sauce, and soy sauce (if using).
cooking_instructions.2: Soak tapioca pearls: Briefly rinse the tapioca pearls and let them soak in just enough water to moisten them (not submerged). This step is crucial to prevent the pearls from becoming overly sticky.
cooking_instructions.3: Form the dumplings: Take a small amount of the soaked tapioca pearls and flatten it in your palm. Place a small spoonful of the pork filling in the center.
cooking_instructions.4: Close and shape: Gently close the tapioca pearl mixture around the filling, forming a small ball or slightly flattened dumpling.
cooking_instructions.5: Steam the dumplings: Line a steamer basket with banana leaves or parchment paper to prevent sticking. Place the Sakoo Sai Moo in the steamer, leaving some space between each one.
cooking_instructions.6: Steam until translucent: Steam over medium heat for approximately 15-20 minutes, or until the tapioca pearls become translucent and the filling is cooked through.
cooking_instructions.7: Serve: Serve hot, garnished with fried garlic or coriander if desired.  Traditionally, it can be served with fresh chili and lettuce wraps.

name: Tao Hoo Tod
description: Tao Hoo Tod, also known as Thai fried tofu, is a popular street food and appetizer in Thailand. Cubes of firm tofu are deep-fried to a golden brown, creating a crispy exterior and a soft, chewy interior.
